questions.text: Which of the following is included in formal of thought disorder?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Formal Thought Disorder: Disturbances in structure and organization of thinking. Most commonly seen in schizophrenia and other psychotic disorder.

Examples for common formal thought disorder:

Loosening of Association: There is no association between two different thoughts or ideas.

  • Q- What is your name?
  • A- I am peon in no one's life become easy.

Derailment- one thought slides into another.

  • I am going to Bangalore. Ramesh is very smart

Omission- senseless omission of a thought or part of it

  • This person Mr..... told me that ....sleep

Fusion- heterogenous elements of thought are interwoven together

  • I am going to very smart

Drivelling- disordered intermixture of constituent parts of one complex thought

  • He shot a bullet. Tiger jumped on him. He went to forest. He shocked.

Substitution- major thought is substituted by a subsidiary one

  • Q - which festival will you celebrate?
  • A - We will celebrate.. at my sister's place

questions.text: A male patient comes with history of marital conflicts and complains of early ejaculation. Which of the following non pharmacological method may be useful in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The squeeze technique is a non-pharmacological approach used to treat premature ejaculation. It involves the partner squeezing the tip or base of the penis just before ejaculation to interrupt the process. This action helps reduce arousal and delay ejaculation. The technique is repeated during subsequent sexual activities to help train the body's response and improve ejaculatory control.

Other options:

B. CBT (Cognitive Behavioural Therapy): While CBT can be helpful in various sexual and psychological disorders, it is not specifically indicated for the treatment of premature ejaculation. CBT focuses on identifying and modifying thought patterns and behaviours that contribute to psychological distress and dysfunction.

C. Exposure and response prevention: This therapeutic approach is commonly used in the treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) and related conditions. It involves exposing the patient to anxiety-provoking situations while preventing the usual compulsive response. It is not a standard treatment for premature ejaculation.

D. Sensate focus technique: The sensate focus technique is a type of sex therapy that involves a series of behavioural exercises to enhance the couple's intimacy and reduce performance anxiety. While it can be beneficial for improving overall sexual satisfaction, it is not a specific treatment for premature ejaculation.

questions.text: Patient with h/o opioid overdose presented with severe respiratory depression. DOC for reversal of respiratory depression
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In cases of opioid overdose, the most critical and life-threatening complication is respiratory depression. Opioids act on the central nervous system, including the brainstem, where they suppress the respiratory drive. This can lead to severely decreased or even stopped breathing, which is a medical emergency.

The drug of choice for reversing opioid-induced respiratory depression is naloxone, an opioid antagonist. Naloxone competitively binds to opioid receptors, displacing the opioids and rapidly reverses the effects of the opioids. It restores normal respiration and can save a person's life during an opioid overdose.

Other options:

A. Oral Naltrexone: Naltrexone is also an opioid antagonist similar to naloxone, but it is not the best choice in an acute opioid overdose situation. Oral naltrexone takes longer to be absorbed and act, making it less suitable for emergencies like severe respiratory depression in an opioid overdose.

C. Buprenorphine: Buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist and antagonist used for opioid replacement therapy and managing opioid use disorder. While it can help with opioid withdrawal and cravings in a controlled setting, it is not the first-line choice for emergency reversal of opioid overdose and respiratory depression.

D. Flumazenil: Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine receptor antagonist used to reverse the effects of benzodiazepine overdose. It is not effective for opioid overdose or respiratory depression caused by opioids.

questions.text: What is the dose range of lithium inmEq/L for acute attacks of mania and long-term maintenance?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The therapeutic range for lithium in acute manic episodes and long-term maintenance is typically considered to be 0.6-1.5 mEq/L. This range allows for effective treatment of bipolar disorder while minimizing the risk of toxicity. Since the levels of the therapeutic range is really narrow, it is important to be careful when taking Lithium with other drugs like ACE inhibitors, NSAIDs, Hydrochlorothiazide.

questions.text: A chronic smoker wanting to quit is treated with which of the following oral medications?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Justification:

A chronic smoker who wants to quit can be treated with Varenicline. Varenicline is a medication specifically designed to help people stop smoking. It works by partially stimulating nicotine receptors in the brain while also blocking nicotine from attaching to these receptors. This dual action reduces nicotine cravings and withdrawal symptoms, making it easier for individuals to quit smoking.

Option B(Muscarine) is incorrect because Muscarine is not a medication used to treat smoking addiction. Muscarine is a naturally occurring alkaloid found in certain mushrooms and is not used for smoking cessation.

Option C(Cevimeline) is also incorrect as Cevimeline is a medication primarily used to stimulate salivary gland function in conditions such as Sjogren's syndrome and it is not indicated for smoking cessation.

Option D(Atropine) is not used for smoking cessation either. Atropine is an anticholinergic medication used for various purposes, such as dilating pupils or treating certain heart conditions, but it is not employed in smoking cessation therapy.

questions.text: The tactile hallucinations seen in cases of chronic cocaine intoxication is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

It feels like Insects are crawling beneath the skin.

Common causes of Tactile hallucination include.

  • Substance abuse or substance withdrawal
  • Psychosis

Cocaine Bug Syndrome is also seen in Cocaine Intoxication. It is the feeling that insects are crawling under the skin. Also known as Ekbom Syndrome or Delusion of Infestation/Parasitosis.

Oneiroid State:

  • Dream like fantastic delusional derangement of Consciousness, characterized by Kaleidoscopic quality of psychopathological experiences where in reality, illusion and hallucination merged into one.
  • Motor and catatonic disturbances

Dipsomania

  • Compulsive Drinking pattern of alcohol.

Carphologia

Also known as floccillation - a condition in which the patient aimlessly plucks or picks, usually at bed clothes or clothing, commonly seen in dementia and delirium.

questions.text: All of the following are essential features of ASD, except;
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is characterized by persistent deficits in social communication and interaction across multiple contexts, as well as restricted, repetitive patterns of behaviour, interests, or activities. However, impairment of cognition is not an essential feature of ASD.

The core symptoms of ASD include:

Difficulty in social communication and interaction, such as deficits in social-emotional reciprocity, nonverbal communicative behaviours used for social interaction, and developing, maintaining, and understanding relationships.

Restricted, repetitive patterns of behaviour, interests, or activities, such as stereotyped or repetitive motor movements, insistence on sameness, highly restricted, fixated interests, and hyper- or hyporeactivity to sensory input or unusual interest in sensory aspects of the environment.

Cognitive abilities in individuals with ASD can vary widely, ranging from intellectual disability to average or above-average intelligence. While some individuals with ASD may have impairments in cognition, it is not a universal feature of the disorder.

questions.text: As per "WHO Mental health gap action plan", which of the following is not a priority condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

C. OCD (Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder) is not listed as a priority condition in the WHO Mental Health Gap Action Programme (mhGAP).

The priority conditions identified by mhGAP include:

Depression

Psychotic conditions including schizophrenia

Suicide

Epilepsy

Dementia

Disorders due to substance use

Mental disorders in children and adolescents (which encompasses developmental and behavioral disorders).

OCD is not specifically mentioned among these priority conditions.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK310851/

questions.text: Which of the following is less associated with korsakoff's psychosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

C. Ophthalmoplegia is less associated with Korsakoff's psychosis.

Korsakoff syndrome, often resulting from thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, primarily presents with symptoms such as significant memory problems (both anterograde and retrograde amnesia), confabulation, and other cognitive deficits. While peripheral neuropathy can occur due to thiamine deficiency and is related to alcohol misuse, ophthalmoplegia (which involves eye movement abnormalities) is more characteristic of Wernicke's encephalopathy, the acute phase that can precede Korsakoff syndrome. Thus, ophthalmoplegia is not a typical symptom associated with Korsakoff's psychosis itself

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430729/

questions.text: Following EEG wave is seen in which phase of sleep cycle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

During REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep, the EEG shows a pattern of activity that is very similar to wakefulness, with low-amplitude, high-frequency waves. The brain is highly active during REM sleep, which is also characterized by rapid eye movements under closed eyelids. In contrast, the other stages of sleep are characterized by different EEG patterns:

NREM I (stage 1): Theta waves and some alpha waves

NREM II (stage 2): Sleep spindles and K-complexes interrupt theta waves

NREM III (slow wave sleep): High-amplitude, low-frequency delta waves

So the EEG pattern most resembling wakefulness, with low-amplitude, high-frequency waves, is seen specifically during REM sleep.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK10996/

questions.text: Who is associated with the concept of 'good-enough mothers'?
questions.solution:
• Winnicott believed that mothers supply a holding environment in which infants are contained and experienced.
  • The mother needs to be 'good-enough' but not perfect, to bring the world to the child and offer empathy for the infant's needs.
  • If the mother is attentive to her baby's needs the infant can become more attuned to his or her own bodily functions and drives; this forms the basis for a gradually evolving sense of self.

questions.text: The following image showing Hierarchy of needs is given by the Psychologist.
questions.solution: Abraham Harold Maslow was an American Psychologist who has created Maslow's Hierarchy of needs depicted here which is a theory of psychological health predicted on fulfilling innate human needs in priority, culminating in self-actualization.

questions.text: All of the following conditions may produce feelings of being 'detached from oneself or from environment,' except:
questions.solution:
• Depersonalization can result from a
    • Medical condition
    • Neurological condition
    • Intoxication
    • Withdrawal from illicit drugs
    • Side effect of medications
    • Panic attacks
    • Phobias
    • PTSD
    • Acute stress disorder
    • Schizophrenia
    • Dissociative disorder
  • Drug related depersonalization is typically transient, but persistent depersonalization can follow an episode of intoxication with a variety of substances, including marijuana, cocaine, and other psychostimulants
  • However, it is rarely seen with caffeine use disorder

choices.text: It involves using magnetic fields to stimulate nerve cells in the brain
Repetitive TMS is a useful treatment in refractory cases of OCD
ECT is preferred over TMS in treatment resistant cases of depression

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Transcranial magnetic stimulation(TMS)?
questions.solution:
Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation(TMS):

  • TMS is an example of non-invasive stimulation of focal regions of the brain using magnetic fields.
  • It can be used for research or therapeutically without the need for anesthesia.
  • TMS involves using magnetic fields to stimulate nerve cells in the brain.
  • Repetitive TMS(rTMS) has a role in the treatment of resistant OCD(Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder).
  • ECT(Electroconvulsive Therapy) is considered the gold standard therapy in treatment-resistant depression and is preferred over TMS for certain cases.

False about Transcranial magnetic stimulation(TMS):

A) It is an invasive procedure

  • TMS is not an invasive procedure; it is a non-invasive neurostimulation technique that uses magnetic fields for brain stimulation.

The other options are true:

B) TMS involves using magnetic fieldsto stimulate nerve cells in the brain.

C) Repetitive TMS(rTMS) is a useful treatmentin refractory cases of OCD. rTMS involves repeated sessions of stimulation.

D) ECT is preferred over TMSin treatment-resistant cases of depression, as ECT is often considered when other treatments, including TMS, have not been effective for severe depression.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in catatonic schizophrenia?
questions.solution: Hallucinations can be seen, but not so prominent. Remaining others are prominent catatonic features.

questions.text: All of the following conditions result due to problems with basal ganglia except:
questions.solution:
There are four main conditions to be aware of that result from problems with the basal ganglia: -

  • Huntington's chorea (caudate nucleus)
  • Wilson's disease (copper deposition in basal ganglia)
  • Parkinson's disease (substantia nigra)
  • Hemiballismus (sub thalamic nucleus)

Multiple sclerosis is demyelinating disease of CNS.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-depressants is least likely to be associated with sedation?
questions.solution: • Sedative antidepressants: TCA, Mirtazapine, Trazadone (SSRI, SNRI – can cause decreased sleep)

questions.text: Which of the following drug is used to improve the performance?
questions.solution: Amphetamines are stimulants, hence improve the performance of a person.

questions.text: Which of the following medical disorder mimics panic attack?
Imbalance of which neurotransmitter is seen in OCD?
questions.solution: Serotonin imbalance is related to pathophysiology of OCD.

choices.text: Irritable and reckless behaviour, exaggerated startle response, increased alertness and difficulty in concentration
Irritable and reckless behaviour, increased alertness, flashbacks, nightmares
Avoidance behaviour, decreased concentration, sleep disturbance
Traumatic amnesia, negative emotions, feelings of detachment, depersonalization

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms describe the hyperarousal spectrum of PTSD?
questions.solution:
• Hyperarousal spectrum in PTSD:
  • Irritable behaviour and angry outbursts (with little or no provocation) typically expressed as verbal or physical aggression toward people or objects
  • Reckless or self-destructive behaviour
  • Hypervigilance (alertness)
  • Exaggerated startle response
  • Problems with concentration
  • Sleep disturbance (e.g., difficulty falling or staying asleep or restless sleep)

choices.text: Pain and stiffness of soft tissues such as muscles, ligaments and tendons is seen
Symptoms should be present for more than one month
Pregabalin and SSRIs are used in treatment

questions.text: Which is false for fibromyalgia?
questions.solution:
Fibromyalgia is characterized by pain and stiffness of the soft tissues, such as muscles, ligaments, and tendons. Local areas of tenderness are referred to as "trigger points."

  • Fibromyalgia most commonly affects women (3 percent)more than men (1 percent), particularly those of working age
  • The etiology of fibromyalgia remains unclear. However, it is often precipitated by stress that causes localized arterial spasms that interfere with perfusion of oxygen in the affected areas
  • According to the 2010 American College of Rheumatology criteria, patients must have widespread pain for at least 3 months at predefined tender points upon palpation
  • Pregabalin, an antiepileptic agent, has been approved by the U. S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for the treatment of pain associated with fibromyalgia
  • The SSRIs and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) antidepressantduloxetine has been reported to be effective in treating patients with this disorder

questions.text: Psychotherapeutic technique proven to be effective in dissociative identity disorder?
questions.solution:
• Treatment option out of these, in dissociative disorders is hypnosis.
  • Hypnosis can be useful for accessing specific alter personality states and their sequestered affects and memories.
  • Hypnosis is also used to create relaxed mental states in which negative life events can be examined without overwhelming anxiety.

questions.text: Klein-Levin syndrome is characterised by all of the following features except:
questions.solution:
• Kleine-Levin syndrome is a relatively rare condition consisting of recurrent periods of prolonged sleep (from which patients may be aroused) with intervening periods of normal sleep and alert waking.
  • During the hypersomniac episodes, wakeful periods are usually marked by withdrawal from social contacts and return to bed at the first opportunity.
  • It predominantly afflicts males in early adolescence; however, it can occur later in life and in females. With few exceptions, the first attack occurs between the ages of 10 and 21 years.
  • In its classic form, the recurrent episodes are associated with extreme sleepiness (18-hour to 20-hour sleep periods), voracious eating, hyper sexuality, and disinhibition (e.g., aggression)
  • Episodes → last for a few days up to several weeks.

choices.text: Weight for height less than 75% of normal

questions.text: Hospitalized management of anorexia nervosa is done on priority in patients with:
questions.solution: Weight for height less than 80% of expected is an indication for admission.

choices.text: Lack of remorse/ guilt for their actions

questions.text: All of the following themes are usually present in children with conduct disorder except:
questions.solution:
• Individuals with conduct disorder can exhibit a persistent interpersonal and emotional pattern that can be characterized by at least two of the following:
    1. Lack of remorse or guilt
    2. Callous lack of empathy
    3. Unconcerned about performance
    4. Shallow or deficient affect.
  • Communication skills, however, are not lacking in those with conduct disorder.

choices.text: Those who attempt suicide and survive
Those who attempt suicide and survive with some disability

questions.text: 'Suicide survivor' is defined as:
questions.solution: To be a suicide survivor refers to those who have lost a loved one to suicide (CORRECT OPTION-A), not to someone who has attempted suicide but lived.

choices.text: Make the decision to consent to sexual relationship
Earn money and open a bank account
Be held accountable for their criminal actions

questions.text: Age of responsibility refers to the age at which an individual can:
questions.solution:
• The age of criminal responsibility is the age below which a child is deemed incapable of having committed a criminal offence.
  • In legal terms, it is referred to as a defence of infancy, which is a form of defense known as an excuse so that defendants falling within the definition of an "infant" are excluded from criminal liability for their actions, if at the relevant time, they had not reached an age of criminal responsibility.
  • Nothing is an offence which is done by a child under Indian Penal Code the age of seven years.
  • The age of criminal responsibility is raised to 12 years if the child is found to have not attained the ability of understanding the nature and consequences of his act.

choices.text: She is expected to have lower IQ as compared to general population
Verbal performance dissociation would be commonly seen while performing her IQ test
Her mathematical ability is expected to be reduced as compared to general population
Verbal skills would be higher if the X chromosome is paternally derived

questions.text: The following figure is of a 14-year-old girl who has presented with primary amenorrhoea. Which of the following statement is false regarding her intelligence?
questions.solution:
• In general, girls with Turner show a disharmonic IQ profile.
  • The full-scale IQ is comparable to general population.
  • Reduced performance IQ(at least 20 points or 1 standard deviation lower) though verbal IQ is preserved.
  • Specific subtests assessing visuospatial processing such as 'Block Design' and 'Object Assembly' may be affected more than others.
  • Mathematical ability may also be lower than expected.
  • This specific profile persists into adulthood. Females with a 45X karyotype(Turner syndrome) may have higher verbal skills if their only X chromosome is paternally derived instead of being maternal origin(most commonly it is maternal).
  • This suggests the existence of an imprinted gene that is inactive if carried on a maternally derived X chromosome.

choices.text: Lethal dose for ending life is given by physician
Lethal dose for ending life is prescribed by physician and taken by the patient by self
Lethal dose for ending life is done by switching off the life support systems of the patient

questions.text: What is meant by Physician Assisted suicide?
questions.solution: • Physician-assisted suicide can involve providing information on ways of committing suicide, supplying a prescription for a lethal dose of medication for the patient to take or a means of inhaling a lethal amount of carbon monoxide, or perhaps even providing a suicide device that the patient can operate.
